newsitem.title: LEBANON: Solidere stars in trade in Beirut.
newsitem.headline: Solidere stars in trade in Beirut.

text.p: Solidere shares continued to rise on the Beirut Stock Exchange in the week ended on Friday and brokers said the company's shares shone in a stable market which encouraged Arab investors to buy 30 percent of traded shares.
Solidere A shares rose 4.5 percent to $11.5 from last week's $11 and B shares rose 11.4 percent to $12.25 from $11.

"Solidere shares played star this week in a stable market after last week's rise of the company's Global Depositary Receeipts in London and due to dividend declaration expected before the end of May," Samar Assaf, a broker for Fidus told Reuters.
The GDRs, issued last November at $11.5 on the London Stock Exchange, rose last week to $17.625 from $12 a week earlier. It closed at $15.875.
This week prices were the highest since January 1996 when Solidere, Lebanon's biggest company, still traded its shares on the private Beirut Seondary Market.
It switched to the BSE last September and the private market no longer operates.
Assaf said Arab investors, encouraged by last week's rise of Solidere shares, bought nearly 30 percent of the 590,270 traded shares this week.
The Solidere rise helped the LISPI and BLOM general indices rise 1.56 percent and 5.66 percent to 88.37 and 1,008 respectively. The LIBX bank index rose 1.23 percent to 139.75.

Among the three listed banks only shares of Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce rose 3.8 percent to $17.25 from $16.625 on last Friday while Bank of Beirut and Banque Audi held steady on $3.5625 and $20.125 respectively.

Total BSE turnover for the week shortened to three days by public holidays was 970,240 shares for a value of $9,687,292 against 938,421 shares for a value of $8,133,821 for during also three working days last week.

Of the four listed industrial companies Eternit rose to $1.875 from $1.8125, Ciments Libanaise fell slightly to $1.2812 from $1.28125 and Ciments Blancs fell to $4.75 from $5. There was no trade in tilemaker Uniceramic.
